text.p: The following are the main stories from Friday's Albanian newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Students, who toppled the communist dictatorship exactly six years ago, have asked the government to improve conditions in their hostels.
- Students in the southern town of Gjirokaster protested peacefully over the lack of improvement of living conditions and police violence against a fellow student.

- Azem Hajdari, the December 1990 student revolution leader and currently head of the Independent Trade Unions, called on students to wake up otherwise they would help let a dictatorship be built, just like their fathers did.

- Hajdari has refused to attend a party celebrating the ruling Democratic Party's December 12 anniversary because he was suspended from its national council after coming to lead the Independent Trade Unions.
- Albanian President Sali Berisha's daughter has given birth to a daughter.
- Alleged members of a criminal gang charged with a fatal bombing and political assassination have gone on hunger strike to protest against a ban barring them from meeting their families.
- A Greek farmers revolt has cut off Albania from its important imports. Prices have risen, the money market has been shaken.
- The key opposition Socialist Party has called for a fresh general election in 1997.
- A seven percent tax increase on flour imports may cause a rise in bread prices.
- Mining trade unions are pressing the government to cancel a contract with an Italian company saying it is hindering privatisation.
